title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 15 march [1867]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 15 March [1867]
text: 15 March 67M 15 my dear walteri just write a line to you this fridayFriday morning before breakfast to say we are all about the same and that i got the ten dollars and the 5 of last week and envelopes all come safe) it is very cold again here you say walt for me to get some body to come and help me i shall certainly do so for i find i cantcan't doodo much in the way of any thinganything that is laborious itsit's hard to give up but old age will creep on us jeff and matty went to the funeral of the doctor poor Dr ruggles is gone forever he was buried at greenwoods)Green-wood) george was up yesterday he is well but begins to look quite old jeff is to let him have 200 dollars he is in hopes of selling one to a sea captain if he does they will get along very well) matty still has company mrs mason i felt walt as if i must write a line or two i am still troubled with my wrist and my thumb it pains me some but i feel thankful i can dress myself and doodo around Walt think you come home you said maybeemaybe you would dontdon't let the sleeping part hinder you i can manage it very well i want to see you very much good bie walter dearL W last evening sis swallowed a penny jeff was very much alarmed about it but she is bright enoughfenough now Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 15 March [1867]
